metadata.disclaimer: Based on publicly available crosswalks and expert analysis. Validate with qualified assessors for compliance/audit use.

clauses.title: Understanding the organization and its context
clauses.rationale: RA-03 covers risk context; PM-08/PM-11 cover mission/business process definition. PM-32 (Purposing) adds analysis of systems supporting missions and business functions. ISO 27001 clause 4.1 requires broader organizational context analysis including external/internal issues beyond pure security risk.
clauses.gaps: No direct SP 800-53 control for analyzing external/internal issues (political, economic, social factors) affecting ISMS. Organizational context determination is broader than security risk assessment.

clauses.title: Understanding the needs and expectations of interested parties
clauses.rationale: PM-08 addresses critical infrastructure plan; PM-11 mission/business process definition; SR-01, SR-02, SR-03 address supply chain stakeholder relationships. These partially address stakeholder needs but ISO requires systematic identification of all interested parties and their requirements.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 lacks explicit requirement to identify all interested parties (regulators, customers, partners) and their specific ISMS expectations. Stakeholder mapping and requirements analysis not directly covered.

clauses.title: Determining the scope of the ISMS
clauses.rationale: PM-01 (information security program plan) and PM-10 (authorization process) help define boundaries. PM-07 helps identify system inventory. PL-10 (Baseline Selection) requires determining the systems and boundaries for which baselines apply, supporting scope definition.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 defines system boundaries per authorization but doesn't explicitly require ISMS scope statement. Multi-system/enterprise scope determination differs from individual system authorization boundaries.

clauses.title: Information security management system
clauses.rationale: PM family establishes program-level controls. PM-01 defines program plan; PM-02 assigns roles; PM-03 covers resources; PM-06 measures effectiveness. PL-09 (Central Management) adds centralized management of selected controls and processes across the organization, supporting ISMS as a coherent management system.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 doesn't use PDCA/process approach terminology. Continuous improvement cycle and ISMS as a formal management system with documented processes is implicit rather than explicit.

clauses.title: Leadership and commitment
clauses.rationale: PM-01 requires senior official for security program; PM-02 assigns risk management roles; PM-13 addresses security workforce. PM-29 (Risk Management Program Leadership) specifically addresses senior leadership roles in risk management. Leadership accountability is addressed but ISO requires more explicit top management commitment.
clauses.gaps: SP 800-53 doesn't explicitly require top management to demonstrate commitment through resource allocation, communication of importance, or ensuring ISMS achieves intended outcomes.

clauses.title: Policy
clauses.rationale: PL-01 directly requires security planning policy with management approval. PM-01 requires information security program plan. Policy establishment, approval, and communication well covered.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifies policy must be 'appropriate to the purpose of the organization' and 'available as documented information' with specific distribution requirements.

clauses.title: Organizational roles, responsibilities, and authorities
clauses.rationale: PM-02 directly assigns information security responsibilities. PL-01 covers planning roles. PS-01 covers personnel security roles. PS-09 (Position Descriptions) explicitly requires incorporating security and privacy roles into organizational position descriptions, directly supporting ISO's requirement to assign and communicate responsibilities.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. With PS-09, the requirement for security responsibilities to be incorporated into position descriptions is now explicitly covered.

clauses.title: Actions to address risks and opportunities
clauses.rationale: RA family directly addresses risk assessment. PM-09 covers risk management strategy. RA-03 is comprehensive risk assessment. RA-07 (Risk Response) explicitly addresses responding to risk findings with options including mitigation, acceptance, sharing, or avoidance. PL-10/PL-11 (Baseline Selection/Tailoring) address systematic control selection and customization to address identified risks.
clauses.gaps: ISO explicitly requires considering 'opportunities' alongside risks. SP 800-53 is risk-focused but doesn't explicitly address opportunities for improvement. Risk acceptance criteria less formalized.

clauses.title: Information security risk treatment
clauses.rationale: RA-03 covers risk assessment; PM-09 risk strategy; CA-05 plan of action and milestones for risk treatment. RA-07 (Risk Response) directly addresses risk treatment decisions including mitigating, accepting, sharing, or avoiding risk. PL-10/PL-11 cover baseline selection and tailoring as a systematic risk treatment approach.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit Statement of Applicability (SoA) document. SP 800-53 doesn't have a direct SoA equivalent, though system security plans and baseline tailoring serve a similar purpose.

clauses.title: Information security objectives and planning to achieve them
clauses.rationale: PM-01 includes program objectives; PM-03 addresses resource planning; PM-06 covers security measures of performance. Objective-setting partially covered.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires measurable security objectives at relevant functions/levels with explicit plans (what, resources, responsible, completion, evaluation). SP 800-53 is less prescriptive about objective-setting methodology.

clauses.title: Planning of changes
clauses.rationale: CM-03 covers configuration change control; CM-04 impact analysis; SA-10 developer change management. Change planning well addressed from technical perspective.
clauses.gaps: ISO 6.3 is about planned changes to the ISMS itself (management system changes), not just technical changes. Organizational/process changes to the ISMS are not directly covered.

clauses.title: Resources
clauses.rationale: PM-03 directly addresses information security resources. SA-03 covers system development life cycle resources. SA-02 (Allocation of Resources) addresses determining resource requirements and including security in capital planning and investment control.
clauses.gaps: ISO requirement is broader - all resources needed for ISMS establishment, implementation, maintenance, and continual improvement. Budget allocation and resource planning less prescriptive in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Competence
clauses.rationale: PM-13 directly addresses security workforce/competence. AT-02/AT-03 cover awareness and training. PM-16 covers threat awareness. AT-06 (Training Feedback) provides feedback on training results to senior personnel, supporting competence evaluation and continuous improvement of training programs.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires retaining documented evidence of competence (training records, certifications). AT-04 handles training records; AT-06 adds evaluation feedback loop.

clauses.title: Awareness
clauses.rationale: AT-02 directly covers security awareness training including policy awareness, roles/responsibilities, and consequences. Very well aligned with ISO requirement.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. AT-02 covers awareness of policy, contribution to ISMS effectiveness, and implications of non-conformance.

clauses.title: Communication
clauses.rationale: PM-01 includes communication aspects of security program; PL-04 covers rules of behavior communication; IR-07 covers incident reporting communication.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires determining what, when, with whom, and how to communicate regarding ISMS. SP 800-53 lacks a systematic communication planning control. Internal/external communication strategy not explicitly required.

clauses.title: Documented information
clauses.rationale: PL-02 (system security plan) and PM-01 (program plan) address documentation. AU family covers audit records. Documentation requirements partially met.
clauses.gaps: ISO has specific requirements for documented information control (creation, updating, version control, distribution, access, storage, disposal). SP 800-53 doesn't have a unified document management control.

clauses.title: Operational planning and control
clauses.rationale: PL-02 covers system security plan implementation; PM-01 covers program implementation; CA-02 covers assessment of controls. PL-09 (Central Management) adds centralized operational management of controls. PL-10/PL-11 (Baseline Selection/Tailoring) support systematic operational control selection.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires organizations to plan, implement, and control processes needed to meet requirements. Outsourced process control and documented evidence of process execution are gaps.

clauses.title: Information security risk assessment
clauses.rationale: RA-03 directly covers risk assessment at planned intervals or when significant changes occur. RA-05 covers vulnerability assessment. RA-09 (Criticality Analysis) adds identification of critical system components and functions, strengthening risk assessment with asset criticality determination.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. RA-03 comprehensively covers risk assessment execution, and RA-09 adds critical component identification. ISO emphasizes retaining documented results.

clauses.title: Information security risk treatment
clauses.rationale: CA-05 (POA&M) addresses risk treatment plans. PM-04 tracks system-level plans. RA-03 includes risk response identification. RA-07 (Risk Response) explicitly addresses risk treatment with options for mitigation, acceptance, sharing, or avoidance, closely aligning with ISO risk treatment concepts.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires retaining documented results of risk treatment. POA&M process is close but doesn't perfectly map to ISO risk treatment plan format.

clauses.title: Monitoring, measurement, analysis and evaluation
clauses.rationale: CA-07 (continuous monitoring) and PM-06 (measures of performance) directly address monitoring and measurement. SI-04 covers system monitoring. PM-14 (Testing, Training, and Monitoring) addresses testing and monitoring activities.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires determining what to monitor, methods, when, who analyzes results. PM-06 is less prescriptive about evaluation methods and timing.

clauses.title: Internal audit
clauses.rationale: CA-02 covers security assessments (functionally equivalent to audits). CA-07 continuous monitoring. AU-06 audit review.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal internal audit program with defined criteria, scope, frequency, methods, and auditor independence. CA-02 covers assessments but doesn't use audit terminology or require audit program management.

clauses.title: Management review
clauses.rationale: PM-01 requires periodic program review; PM-06 covers performance measurement. These partially address management review.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifies detailed management review inputs (audit results, stakeholder feedback, risk assessment changes, opportunities for improvement) and outputs (decisions, resource changes). SP 800-53 lacks formal management review structure.

clauses.title: Continual improvement
clauses.rationale: CA-07 continuous monitoring supports improvement; PM-06 measures effectiveness; PM-01 includes program updates.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit continual improvement processes for ISMS suitability, adequacy, and effectiveness. SP 800-53 supports continuous monitoring but doesn't explicitly require PDCA-style continual improvement methodology.

clauses.title: Nonconformity and corrective action
clauses.rationale: CA-05 (POA&M) addresses remediation of identified weaknesses. PM-04 tracks remediation plans. RA-07 (Risk Response) addresses responding to findings from assessments and audits, aligning with corrective action requirements.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal nonconformity management including root cause analysis, corrective action implementation, and effectiveness review. POA&M process is close but lacks formal nonconformity management structure.

clauses.title: Policies for information security
clauses.rationale: SP 800-53 has extensive policy controls (-01 controls) for every family. PL-01 is the overarching planning policy. PM-01 establishes program plan. PT-01 and SR-01 (new in Rev 5) add privacy and supply chain policy requirements for comprehensive policy framework.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 policy requirements are more granular (per-family) while ISO expects a coherent policy set.

clauses.title: Information security roles and responsibilities
clauses.rationale: PM-02 directly assigns senior information security role. PS-01 covers personnel security roles. PS-09 (Position Descriptions) explicitly requires incorporating security and privacy roles into organizational position descriptions, strengthening role definition coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. With PS-09, ISO's requirement for defined security roles and responsibilities is comprehensively addressed.

clauses.title: Segregation of duties
clauses.rationale: AC-05 directly addresses separation of duties. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Management responsibilities
clauses.rationale: PM-02 covers management roles; PM-13 workforce management; PS-01 personnel policies. PM-29 (Risk Management Program Leadership) adds explicit senior leadership roles and accountability for security management.
clauses.gaps: ISO emphasizes management requiring personnel to apply security per policies. SP 800-53 is less explicit about management enforcement responsibility.

clauses.title: Contact with authorities
clauses.rationale: IR-06 covers incident reporting to authorities. PM-15 covers contacts with security groups/associations.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes proactive relationship maintenance with authorities, not just incident reporting.

clauses.title: Contact with special interest groups
clauses.rationale: PM-15 directly covers contacts with security groups and associations. PM-16 covers threat awareness sharing.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Threat intelligence
clauses.rationale: PM-16 addresses threat awareness program. SI-05 covers security alerts and advisories. RA-03/RA-05 include threat identification. RA-10 (Threat Hunting) adds proactive cyber threat hunting capability to search for indicators of compromise and detect advanced threats.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 with RA-10 is comprehensive on threat intelligence, including proactive threat hunting.

clauses.title: Information security in project management
clauses.rationale: SA-03 covers security in SDLC; SA-04 acquisition security requirements; PM-07 enterprise architecture.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically requires security in ALL project management regardless of project type. SA controls focus on system/software projects specifically.

clauses.title: Inventory of information and other associated assets
clauses.rationale: CM-08 directly covers system component inventory. PM-05 covers system inventory. CM-12 (Information Location) identifies and documents the location of information types and the specific system components on which information is processed and stored, directly addressing ISO's requirement for an inventory of information assets.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes 'associated assets' beyond information and system components. CM-12 significantly strengthens the information asset inventory mapping.

clauses.title: Acceptable use of information and other associated assets
clauses.rationale: PL-04 directly covers rules of behavior / acceptable use. AC-20 covers use of external systems.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Return of assets
clauses.rationale: PS-04 covers personnel termination including return of organizational assets.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Classification of information
clauses.rationale: RA-02 covers security categorization of information and systems. Well aligned.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO uses classification levels; SP 800-53 uses FIPS 199 categorization. Conceptually similar but terminology/methodology differs.

clauses.title: Labelling of information
clauses.rationale: MP-03 covers media marking/labeling. RA-02 supports categorization for labeling. AC-16 (Security and Privacy Attributes) supports association of attributes with information for labeling and access control purposes.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO covers labeling of all information forms; MP-03 focuses on media but AC-16 addresses digital labeling.

clauses.title: Information transfer
clauses.rationale: SC-07 boundary protection; SC-08 transmission confidentiality/integrity; AC-04 information flow enforcement; AC-20 external system use. CA-03 (Information Exchange) addresses information exchange agreements with external systems.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes transfer agreements and policies for all forms (electronic, physical, verbal). SP 800-53 focuses on technical controls but CA-03 adds exchange agreements.

clauses.title: Access control
clauses.rationale: AC family is comprehensive. AC-01 policy; AC-02 account management; AC-03 access enforcement; AC-06 least privilege; AC-17 remote access.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 AC family is more detailed than ISO requirement.

clauses.title: Identity management
clauses.rationale: IA family comprehensively covers identification and authentication. IA-04 identifier management; IA-05 authenticator management. IA-12 (Identity Proofing) covers identity verification before credential issuance.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Authentication information
clauses.rationale: IA-05 directly covers authenticator management (passwords, tokens, etc.). IA-06 covers authenticator feedback.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Access rights
clauses.rationale: AC-02 covers account management including provisioning, review, and revocation. AC-06 covers least privilege. AC-25 covers reference monitor concept.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information security in supplier relationships
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition security requirements; SA-09 external system services; SR family covers supply chain risk.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes ongoing supplier relationship management and periodic review. SP 800-53 focuses more on acquisition-time requirements.

clauses.title: Addressing information security within supplier agreements
clauses.rationale: SA-04 directly requires security requirements in acquisitions. SA-09 covers service agreements. SR-03 covers supply chain controls and processes in agreements.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires specific agreement terms for information protection. SA-04 is comprehensive but format differs.

clauses.title: Managing information security in the ICT supply chain
clauses.rationale: SR family comprehensively addresses supply chain risk management including ICT supply chain. SR-05 covers acquisition strategies; SR-06 supplier assessments; SR-11 component authenticity.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 SR family is well aligned with ISO supply chain requirements.

clauses.title: Monitoring, review and change management of supplier services
clauses.rationale: SA-09 includes external service monitoring; SR-06 supplier assessments; CA-07 continuous monitoring.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires regular monitoring and review of supplier service delivery, change management of supplier services. SP 800-53 is less prescriptive about ongoing supplier service monitoring cadence.

clauses.title: Information security for use of cloud services
clauses.rationale: SA-09 covers external information system services (includes cloud); AC-20 external systems; SC-07 boundary protection.
clauses.gaps: ISO 27001:2022 added cloud-specific control. SP 800-53 addresses cloud through general external service controls but lacks cloud-specific acquisition, use, management, and exit requirements. FedRAMP supplements this.

clauses.title: Information security incident management planning and preparation
clauses.rationale: IR-01 covers incident response policy; IR-02 training; IR-03 testing; IR-08 incident response plan. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Assessment and decision on information security events
clauses.rationale: IR-04 incident handling; IR-05 incident monitoring; IR-06 incident reporting. Well covered.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Response to information security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-04 comprehensively covers incident response. IR-06 reporting; IR-07 assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Learning from information security incidents
clauses.rationale: IR-03 includes lessons learned; IR-04 includes incident analysis. Post-incident review addressed.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes using incident knowledge to reduce future likelihood/impact systematically. SP 800-53 less prescriptive on knowledge management from incidents.

clauses.title: Collection of evidence
clauses.rationale: IR-04 includes evidence collection; AU-03 content of audit records; AU-06 audit review; AU-11 audit record retention.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO focuses on digital forensics evidence handling for legal proceedings. SP 800-53 covers audit records but evidence handling for legal admissibility less explicit.

clauses.title: Information security during disruption
clauses.rationale: CP family comprehensively covers continuity planning, testing, and recovery. Strong alignment.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: ICT readiness for business continuity
clauses.rationale: CP family covers IT contingency planning including alternate processing, telecommunications, recovery. CP-13 addresses alternative security mechanisms.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO emphasizes ICT readiness specifically supporting business continuity plans. SP 800-53 focuses on IT contingency but connection to broader BCP is implicit.

clauses.title: Legal, statutory, regulatory and contractual requirements
clauses.rationale: PL-04 includes compliance obligations; PM-01 addresses regulatory compliance; SA-04 contractual requirements.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires explicit identification and documentation of all legal/regulatory/contractual requirements. SP 800-53 lacks a dedicated legal compliance identification control. FISMA context assumes federal requirements.

clauses.title: Intellectual property rights
clauses.rationale: No direct SP 800-53 control for intellectual property management.
clauses.gaps: Significant gap. SP 800-53 does not address software licensing, copyright compliance, or IP protection. Requires supplementary organizational controls.

clauses.title: Protection of records
clauses.rationale: AU-11 covers audit record retention; SI-12 covers information management and retention.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires protection of records from loss, destruction, falsification per legal/regulatory requirements. SP 800-53 covers retention but broader records management (classification, disposal schedules) less explicit.

clauses.title: Privacy and protection of PII
clauses.rationale: PT family (added in Rev 5) directly addresses privacy. PM-25 minimization; PM-26 complaint management; PM-27 privacy reporting.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO defers to ISO 27701 for full privacy coverage. SP 800-53 PT family is comprehensive for PII protection.

clauses.title: Independent review of information security
clauses.rationale: CA-02 covers security assessments which serve as independent reviews. CA-07 continuous monitoring; PM-06 performance measurement.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires independent review of the ISMS approach, not just technical control assessment. Management system review independence less explicit in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Compliance with policies, rules and standards
clauses.rationale: CA-02 assesses compliance; AU-06 reviews audit records for compliance; PM-06 measures performance.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires regular review that information processing complies with policies. SP 800-53 assessment approach differs from compliance checking methodology.

clauses.title: Documented operating procedures
clauses.rationale: PL-02 covers system security plans documenting procedures; SA-05 system documentation; CM-01 configuration management procedures.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires documented operating procedures for information processing facilities. SP 800-53 has family-specific procedures but no unified operating procedures control.

clauses.title: Screening
clauses.rationale: PS-03 directly covers personnel screening before access is granted.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Terms and conditions of employment
clauses.rationale: PS-06 covers access agreements; PL-04 covers rules of behavior. PS-09 (Position Descriptions) requires security responsibilities in position descriptions which directly relates to employment terms and conditions.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes security responsibilities in employment contracts. SP 800-53 focuses on access agreements and position descriptions rather than employment contract terms, but PS-09 strengthens coverage.

clauses.title: Information security awareness, education and training
clauses.rationale: AT-02 awareness training; AT-03 role-based training; AT-04 training records; PM-13 workforce program. AT-06 (Training Feedback) provides feedback on training results to senior personnel, enabling continuous improvement of training programs.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. AT-06 strengthens the training evaluation cycle.

clauses.title: Disciplinary process
clauses.rationale: PS-08 covers personnel sanctions for security violations.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires formal disciplinary process communicated to employees. PS-08 addresses sanctions but formal process establishment less detailed.

clauses.title: Responsibilities after termination or change of employment
clauses.rationale: PS-04 covers personnel termination; PS-05 covers personnel transfer. Both address ongoing responsibilities.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. PS-04/PS-05 address access revocation and ongoing obligations.

clauses.title: Confidentiality or non-disclosure agreements
clauses.rationale: PS-06 covers access agreements which include confidentiality requirements.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically requires NDAs reflecting organizational needs. PS-06 is broader (access agreements) and NDA specifics are less detailed.

clauses.title: Remote working
clauses.rationale: AC-17 directly covers remote access controls. PE-17 covers alternate work sites.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes remote working security policies and risk considerations beyond technical access controls (physical environment, clean desk at home).

clauses.title: Information security event reporting
clauses.rationale: IR-06 directly covers incident reporting. IR-07 covers incident response assistance.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical security perimeters
clauses.rationale: PE-03 covers physical access control; PE-04 covers access control for transmission medium.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Physical entry
clauses.rationale: PE-02 physical access authorizations; PE-03 physical access control; PE-06 monitoring; PE-08 visitor access records.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. Comprehensive physical entry controls.

clauses.title: Securing offices, rooms and facilities
clauses.rationale: PE-03 physical access control; PE-05 access control for output devices.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes broader facility security design considerations.

clauses.title: Physical security monitoring
clauses.rationale: PE-06 directly covers monitoring physical access. PE-08 access logs.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Protecting against physical and environmental threats
clauses.rationale: PE family comprehensively covers environmental protections: power (PE-09,11), fire (PE-13), temperature (PE-14), water (PE-15). PE-23 (Facility Location) adds planning facility location considering physical and environmental hazards, directly addressing threat protection at the site selection level.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. PE-23 strengthens coverage by addressing hazard considerations in facility location planning.

clauses.title: Working in secure areas
clauses.rationale: PE-02/PE-03 control access; PE-07 addresses visitor control in secure areas.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes rules for working in secure areas (no cameras, supervised work). SP 800-53 less specific about behavioral controls in secure areas.

clauses.title: Clear desk and clear screen
clauses.rationale: AC-11 covers session lock (clear screen). MP-04 covers media storage.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO explicitly addresses clear desk policy. AC-11 covers screen; desk policy is implied through MP controls but not explicitly stated.

clauses.title: Equipment siting and protection
clauses.rationale: PE-14 covers environmental controls; PE-18 location of components. PE-23 (Facility Location) addresses planning facility/site location considering physical and environmental hazards, supporting equipment siting decisions.
clauses.gaps: ISO includes equipment placement to minimize unauthorized access and environmental hazards. SP 800-53 less specific about equipment siting methodology but PE-23 adds site-level considerations.

clauses.title: Security of assets off-premises
clauses.rationale: AC-17 remote access; MP-05 media transport; SC-28 protection of information at rest.
clauses.gaps: ISO covers all off-premises assets (laptops, paper, etc.). SP 800-53 covers media and remote access but physical asset protection off-site less comprehensive.

clauses.title: Storage media
clauses.rationale: MP family comprehensively covers media protection: policy (MP-01), access (MP-02), marking (MP-03), storage (MP-04), transport (MP-05), sanitization (MP-06), use (MP-07). MP-08 (Media Downgrading) adds media downgrading procedures.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Supporting utilities
clauses.rationale: PE-09 power equipment protection; PE-10 emergency shutoff; PE-11 emergency power; PE-12 emergency lighting.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Cabling security
clauses.rationale: PE-04 covers access control for transmission medium. PE-09 covers power equipment/cabling protection.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes specific cabling security measures (protected routing, shielding). PE-04 is more general.

clauses.title: Equipment maintenance
clauses.rationale: MA family comprehensively covers maintenance: policy (MA-01), controlled maintenance (MA-02), tools (MA-03), nonlocal (MA-04), personnel (MA-05), timely (MA-06). MA-07 (Field Maintenance) adds controls for restricting field maintenance on critical components to trusted facilities.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. MA-07 strengthens coverage for maintenance of critical equipment.

clauses.title: Secure disposal or re-use of equipment
clauses.rationale: MP-06 covers media sanitization; MP-07 covers media use restrictions. PM-32 (Purposing) addresses analyzing systems and components for suitability for reuse, directly supporting secure re-use assessment.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO includes all equipment disposal; SP 800-53 focuses on media specifically but PM-32 adds system/component reuse analysis.

clauses.title: User endpoint devices
clauses.rationale: AC-19 covers access control for mobile devices; CM-07 least functionality; SC-28 protection at rest.
clauses.gaps: ISO covers all user endpoint devices holistically (BYOD, MDM, containerization). SP 800-53 addresses mobile and device management across multiple controls but no unified endpoint control.

clauses.title: Privileged access rights
clauses.rationale: AC-06 directly covers least privilege including privileged access restriction, review, and authorization. Comprehensive coverage.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information access restriction
clauses.rationale: AC-03 access enforcement; AC-04 information flow enforcement; AC-06 least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Access to source code
clauses.rationale: CM-05 covers access restrictions for change; AC-03 access enforcement; SA-10 developer configuration management.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses source code access restrictions. SP 800-53 addresses through configuration management and access controls.

clauses.title: Secure authentication
clauses.rationale: IA-02 identification and authentication; IA-05 authenticator management; IA-08 non-organizational users; IA-11 re-authentication.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Capacity management
clauses.rationale: AU-04 covers audit log storage capacity; SC-05 denial of service protection; CP-02 contingency planning considers capacity. SC-06 (Resource Availability) addresses resource allocation to prevent denial of service by ensuring sufficient processing capacity.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires proactive capacity management for all IT resources. SP 800-53 addresses capacity in specific contexts but lacks a general capacity planning control. SC-06 partially fills the gap.

clauses.title: Protection against malware
clauses.rationale: SI-03 directly covers malicious code protection. SI-08 covers spam protection.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Management of technical vulnerabilities
clauses.rationale: RA-05 vulnerability monitoring and scanning; SI-02 flaw remediation; SI-05 security alerts.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Configuration management
clauses.rationale: CM family comprehensively covers configuration management: baselines (CM-02), change control (CM-03), analysis (CM-04), settings (CM-06), least functionality (CM-07). CM-14 (Signed Components) adds verification of digitally signed components before installation.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Information deletion
clauses.rationale: MP-06 media sanitization; SI-12 information management/retention. SR-12 (Component Disposal) addresses secure component disposal.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses information deletion when no longer required. SP 800-53 covers sanitization and retention but proactive deletion based on business need less explicit.

clauses.title: Data masking
clauses.rationale: SI-19 covers de-identification. PT-06/PT-07 cover data processing minimization.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses data masking techniques (pseudonymization, anonymization, masking). SP 800-53 Rev 5 added privacy controls but masking as a technique is less comprehensively addressed.

clauses.title: Data leakage prevention
clauses.rationale: AC-04 information flow enforcement; SC-07 boundary protection; SI-04 system monitoring; PE-19 information leakage.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses DLP. SP 800-53 covers information flow and monitoring but integrated DLP as a concept is distributed across multiple controls.

clauses.title: Information backup
clauses.rationale: CP-09 directly covers information system backup. CP-06 alternate storage site.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Redundancy of information processing facilities
clauses.rationale: CP-06 alternate storage; CP-07 alternate processing site; CP-08 telecommunications services.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO focuses on redundancy for availability. CP controls focus on contingency which includes redundancy.

clauses.title: Logging
clauses.rationale: AU family comprehensively covers logging: events (AU-02), content (AU-03), storage (AU-04), response (AU-05), review (AU-06), reporting (AU-07), timestamps (AU-08), protection (AU-09), retention (AU-11).
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Monitoring activities
clauses.rationale: SI-04 directly covers system monitoring. AU-06 audit review; CA-07 continuous monitoring; IR-04 incident handling.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Clock synchronization
clauses.rationale: AU-08 directly covers time stamps and clock synchronization.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Use of privileged utility programs
clauses.rationale: CM-07 least functionality restricts utilities; CM-11 user-installed software; AC-06 least privilege.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses privileged utility programs. SP 800-53 addresses through general controls.

clauses.title: Installation of software on operational systems
clauses.rationale: CM-05 access restrictions for change; CM-07 least functionality; CM-11 user-installed software; SA-22 unsupported components. CM-14 (Signed Components) prevents installation of unsigned software, strengthening installation controls.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. CM-14 adds digital signature verification for software installation.

clauses.title: Networks security
clauses.rationale: SC-07 boundary protection; SC-08 transmission confidentiality/integrity; AC-04 information flow. CA-09 (Internal System Connections) addresses authorization, documentation, and review of internal system connections, strengthening network security controls.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. CA-09 adds internal connection authorization and documentation.

clauses.title: Security of network services
clauses.rationale: SC-07/SC-08 cover network security. SA-09 covers external system services including network services.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO requires security features, service levels, and management requirements for network services. Service level specifics less detailed in SP 800-53.

clauses.title: Segregation of networks
clauses.rationale: SC-07 boundary protection with segmentation. SC-32 system partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Web filtering
clauses.rationale: SC-07 boundary protection includes filtering; SI-03 malware protection; AC-04 information flow.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses web filtering. SP 800-53 doesn't have a dedicated web filtering control; addressed through general boundary and content controls.

clauses.title: Use of cryptography
clauses.rationale: SC-12 cryptographic key management; SC-13 cryptographic protection; SC-28 protection of information at rest.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 cryptography controls are comprehensive.

clauses.title: Secure development life cycle
clauses.rationale: SA-03 system development life cycle; SA-08 security engineering; SA-10 developer config management; SA-11 developer testing; SA-15 development process/standards; SA-17 developer security architecture.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap. SP 800-53 SA family is comprehensive for secure development.

clauses.title: Application security requirements
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition process / security requirements in acquisitions. SA-08 security engineering principles.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure system architecture and engineering principles
clauses.rationale: SA-08 security engineering principles; SA-17 developer security architecture; SC-07/SC-32 architecture-level controls.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Secure coding
clauses.rationale: SA-11 developer security testing; SA-15 development process standards; SA-16 developer-provided training; SA-17 security architecture.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses secure coding practices. SP 800-53 addresses through development process and testing controls rather than explicit coding standards.

clauses.title: Security testing in development and acceptance
clauses.rationale: SA-11 directly covers developer security testing. CA-02 security assessments. SA-04 includes testing requirements.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Outsourced development
clauses.rationale: SA-04 acquisition requirements; SA-09 external system services; SA-10/SA-11 developer requirements apply to outsourced development.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO specifically addresses outsourced development supervision and acceptance. SP 800-53 covers through general acquisition controls.

clauses.title: Separation of development, test and production environments
clauses.rationale: CM-04 impact analysis (separate test environments); SA-11 developer testing environment; SC-32 system partitioning.
clauses.gaps: Minor: ISO explicitly requires environment separation. SP 800-53 implies it through testing and partitioning controls but doesn't mandate specific environment separation.

clauses.title: Change management
clauses.rationale: CM-03 configuration change control; CM-04 impact analysis; CM-05 access restrictions for change; SA-10 developer configuration management.
clauses.gaps: Minimal gap.

clauses.title: Test information
clauses.rationale: SA-11 covers testing. SA-15 development process standards.
clauses.gaps: ISO specifically addresses protection of test data (anonymization, controlled access to production data used in testing). SP 800-53 lacks explicit test data management control.

clauses.title: Protection of information systems during audit testing
clauses.rationale: CA-02 covers security assessments including audit considerations. AU-06 audit review analysis. CA-08 (Penetration Testing) addresses planning and execution of security testing with controls to protect systems during testing.
clauses.gaps: ISO requires that audit testing be planned and agreed to minimize business disruption. SP 800-53 assessment controls don't explicitly address protection of systems during audit activities, but CA-08 adds planned penetration testing.
